Award.AwardTitle: PAC-Involved: Engaging Students in PAC (Physics, Astronomy, Cosmology) Learning through Repurposing of Popular Media

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
1311427
Fotiyeva


The Howard University multimedia educational pilot project will design, develop, and test an innovative science education model and materials to motivate high school students in grades 10-11 to become interested in pursuing careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education by learning physics, astronomy, and cosmology (PAC) in multi-modal innovative ways. To accomplish this, the PAC - Involved pilot project team is combining the best features of formal and informal education along with the educative resources offered by networked computing, popular media, and information technologies. The main goal of the project is to pilot test key methods and designs to develop a new learning model that could provide essential science content preparation together with enhancing students? motivation to enroll and succeed in regular high school physics and astronomy courses, which are gateways to college level STEM courses and careers. Over a 2-year period, the PAC - Involved team will design, develop, and test a new learning environment and will work with 30 high school students from the Washington Metropolitan Area Public School Systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to plan, design, and develop a new model of learning environment that increase students’ interest and achievement in high school physics. PAC – Involved project introduced and taught selected high school physics and astronomy topics in an engaging and novel way by repurposing of popular sci-fi movies and TV shows.

The collaborators in the PAC-Involved project included professors associated with multiple departments (curriculum, physics, and astronomy, mathematics, and Integrative STEM education) from Howard University’s School of Education and the College of Arts and Science, and teachers and students from the District of Columbia Metropolitan Area. Project’s goals included students connecting with STEM professionals and the use of their expertise, students’ interaction with rich scientific data and its visualizations, opportunities for additional research, and exposure to innovative learning environments capable of the seamless bridging between formal and informal learning.

Most if not all of the students seemed to be genuinely interested in learning about physics, astronomy, and cosmology. Half the students indicated that they are interested in pursuing science or math in college, pursuing a science or math career, or both. Students said they would recommend PAC-Involved, or they would recommend it only if the student would be interested and attend. Students expressed many positive comments about the program, such as “great experience,” “a lot of knowledge” and “for friends who are not going to college, this trip to Howard University may change their minds.”

The structure of the session was a combination of instructors presenting to students and students engaging in interactive group activity. In Part I of each face-to-face sessions,  the physics professors showed demos, talked, and showed videos. In Part II, the students formed four groups of five students and worked on their own projects with the technology consultant.

Students best liked the interactive components of the program (experiments, popular media video clips, demonstrations, group video project), while they least liked the lectures. Thus, in planning future changes to the program, an idea to consider is to expand the hands-on involved components while shortening the lectures.

Live sessions were accompanied by activities on the project website, which was populated with multiple resources  to enhance participants’ learning and engagement.
